sect2.title: Contextual Factors
sect2.para: Settings: The diagnostic interview in general, and the MSE in particular, may vary somewhat depending on the clinical setting, client population, and referral source. The format of the MSE will depend on both the clinician’s specialty training as well as the intended audience of the clinical documentation. For example, clinicians who work in hospital emergency department and inpatient psychiatric psychiatric settings may be more familiar than their outpatient counterparts with assessing and noting thought disorders and perceptual disturbances, as they may encounter more individuals in a psychotic, manic, or severely agitated state. Clinicians in outpatient mental health clinics see the gamut of mental health conditions but often encounter individuals with a degree of stability and functional success that allows them to live in the community. Nonetheless, such clinicians will likely be aware of the importance of querying for latent symptoms of psychosis psychosis , personality disorders (particularly borderline personality disorder), substance use, and suicidality. Neuropsychologists and neurologists will likely be attuned to signs of motor disturbances and cognitive impairment. Providers across many disciplines and settings (e. g., clinical psychology, psychiatry, social work, rehabilitation medicine, primary care/family medicine, neurology, private practice mental health) use some form of an MSE, although the write-up of the intake evaluation or clinical encounter may take a different form depending on setting. Most importantly, the language of the MSE should facilitate communication among the many professionals who may interact with both the clinical documentation and the client. Clinicians should ground all observations of clients in evidence from the interview interview ; this is critical for other readers of the MSE and may be done through statements, such as “as evidenced by…,” “with…,” “characteristic of…,” “noteworthy behaviors include…,” and the like. The clinician’s goal is to produce a meaningful description of the client, based on observable evidence from the session, which can be easily interpreted by the relevant audience for a given setting. Moreover, a clinician establishes credibility as an interviewer through the ability to cite and describe the various pieces of evidence that support the somewhat subjective nature of this assessment.

Telehealth considerations : Telehealth Telehealth was understudied and underused until the COVID-19 pandemic. Since then, it has been generally well received and widely utilized, has improved accessibility, and will continue to be an integral part of health care. While screening tools exist for remote assessment of cognition such as telephone-based instruments derived from the MoCA (Frank et al., 2020 ), specific limitations related to adapting MSE to telehealth visits are important to consider.

Several of a clinician’s senses—including visual, auditory, and olfactory—commonly utilized in mental status assessment are limited in virtual settings. Creativity must be utilized to maximize the observation and assessment performed performed within a telehealth setting. To assess appearance and gait, ambulatory clients might be asked to walk across the room in view of the camera. Screen sharing can be utilized by the clinician to administer questionnaires such as the PHQ-9. The client’s ability to navigate and interact with the technology used for the appointment can provide valuable information regarding their thought processes, memory, functional ability, and fine and gross motor skills. Furthermore, many elements of the MSE are preserved through telehealth appointments such as clinician’s using visual and auditory observations to assess mood, affect, thinking, memory, insight, etc.

Clinical telehealth policies should include rules regarding whether clients must be visible during sessions and where the sessions can take place (i. e., if the client or therapist is out-of-state or country for work, where licensure may be an issue). To visibly assess for safety, especially when non-suicidal self-injury is a concern, clinicians can ask the client to remain on screen with their camera on for the duration of the appointment. Knowing where the client is located is essential, should an emergency response become necessary. Clinicians should ensure clients are in a quiet, private setting to protect confidentiality. Licensing laws regarding telehealth vary by state, so it is important to adhere to state guidance.

Populations: Varied clinical populations benefit from adjustments to the MSE or additional special considerations, relative to the clinical setting and goals of the evaluation. For all clients, a thorough MSE includes individualized observation and person-centered interpretation. The clinician can increase inclusivity and appropriateness of MSE procedures by considering some additional, population-specific features.

Cultural considerations : The MSE is subjective and influenced by cultural background; for instance, immigrants or those from impoverished backgrounds may lack certain knowledge (e. g., reciting recent US presidents). Non-native English speakers may use different vocabulary to convey subjective experiences. Cultural factors factors like education quality and access affect cognitive assessment. Non-white racial/ethnic minorities may perform differently on standardized tests originally normed and developed in predominantly non-Hispanic white samples. Clinicians should choose assessments considering factors like age, race, education, and culture, ideally administered in the client’s native language.

Neurodevelopmental considerations : When working with individuals with intellectual developmental disorder (IDD) and ASD, sensitivity is crucial due to their unique communication styles, cognitive differences, and attentional challenges. Establishing rapport with both the client and caregiver(s) is essential. Activities like drawing or completing puzzles together may facilitate rapport-building and provide insight into the individual’s typical environment. Consider thought content, emotional expression expression , and psychomotor behavior within the context of a neurodevelopmental condition to avoid misclassification. For instance, someone with ASD may appear indifferent or lack expression, potentially misinterpreted as flat affect seen in schizophrenia. Ideas expressed by those with neurodevelopmental conditions may resemble delusions due to lack of evidence; thus, thorough history-taking and review with knowledgeable caregivers are crucial.

Aging : Developmental considerations are also crucial for aging, older adult clients, as mental disorders often manifest differently with increased age. Age-appropriate assessments are essential (see Segal et al., 2018 ). For instance, older adults with depressive symptoms may express somatic and cognitive complaints rather than sadness, which may be challenging to differentiate from medical concerns (Fiske et al., 2009 ; Haigh et al., 2018 ). Historical context, such as a person’s birth cohort (e. g., the Silent Generation, Baby Boomers), can influence symptom presentation, including a reluctance to disclose emotional vulnerability. Clinicians should be aware of implicit ageist beliefs that may affect appropriate inquiry into substance use, sexual behaviors, and suicidal or homicidal thinking. It’s important to recognize that cognitive decline is just one of many potential concerns for older clients, and that many older individuals will not experience significant cognitive declines at all.

Medical populations : Certain medical conditions may cause altered mental status or expression of psychiatric symptoms. Clinicians should therefore collect medical history whenever possible, and clinicians should ask the client about their past and current medications. Asking about medications may clue the clinician into existing medical conditions which may be contributing to abnormal presentation during the MSE or may alert the clinician to potential drug interactions. Medical populations and older adults are often prescribed multiple medications, compounding the risk for adverse reactions.
